content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Kevin Kozlowski: I was born and raised in Chicago, on the South Side, and I've always had a strong connection to the city. My parents were both working-class folks who didn't have a lot of formal education—my dad worked as a mechanic, and my mom was a nurse's aide. They always emphasized the importance of hard work and doing the right thing, even if they didn't have much to give. I grew up in a tight-knit neighborhood, where everyone knew each other, and I had a pretty typical childhood—playing outside with friends, going to church with my family when I was younger, and always being encouraged to do well in school. I was the first in my family to go to college, which was a big deal for them. I ended up studying business, which I thought would give me a good foundation for whatever I wanted to do. After college, I landed a job in marketing, and I've been working full time ever since. I've never been married, and I've always been focused on my career and personal growth. Life hasn't been without its challenges, but I've always tried to stay grounded and make the best of what I have.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Kevin Kozlowski: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was in my second year of college, studying business, and I had this internship opportunity at a local startup that was doing some pretty cool work in the tech space. At the same time, my parents were going through a tough time financially—my dad had gotten laid off, and my mom was working double shifts. I felt like I needed to step in and help out, so I almost turned down the internship to take a part-time job at a local store to support them. But then I talked to my mom one night, and she said something that stuck with me. She told me, 'You have to think about your future, Kevin. We'll manage somehow, but if you don't take this chance, you'll always wonder what could have been.' That really hit me. I took the internship, and it changed everything. I got exposed to a whole new world of possibilities, met people who became mentors, and it ultimately led me to the career I have today. I think that moment defined me because it taught me the importance of balancing responsibility with ambition, and it showed me that sometimes the hardest decisions are the ones that lead to the most growth.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Kevin Kozlowski: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made easily. I had to weigh my responsibilities to my family against my own dreams, and it wasn't just about one decision—it was about how I approached everything after that. I remember lying awake at night, thinking about what my mom said, and realizing that she wasn't just being selfless; she was giving me a chance to build something better for both of us. So I made the choice to take the internship, but I also made a promise to myself that I wouldn't forget where I came from. That decision didn't just shape my career—it shaped who I am as a person. I think that's what makes it so meaningful. It wasn't just about taking a path; it was about understanding the weight of the choices we make and the impact they have on the people we love.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Kevin Kozlowski: Absolutely, I think a lot of people or organizations could have helped. My parents were pretty proud and didn't want to burden anyone else, but looking back, I wish I had reached out more to the community centers or local nonprofits that were around. There were programs for families in need, and I think if I had taken advantage of those, it might have eased some of the pressure on my parents. I also think my college advisors could have done more to connect me with financial aid or work-study opportunities. It's funny, though—I didn't realize how much support was out there at the time. I guess that's another lesson: sometimes we don't ask for help because we don't want to seem like we're struggling, but in the end, it's better to ask than to suffer in silence.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Kevin Kozlowski: I don't have a partner or children right now, but family is still a huge part of my life. My parents are still in Chicago, and even though they've both retired, they're doing well. My mom still volunteers at the local hospital, and my dad keeps himself busy with some side projects around the house. I visit them as much as I can, especially on holidays or weekends when work isn't too demanding. I also have a few cousins who live in the area, and we keep in touch—sometimes we get together for family dinners or just hang out at the park. I think the most important thing for me is that I've never lost touch with where I came from. Even though I've built a life for myself, I always make sure to stay connected to my roots. I guess I'm not ready for a partner or kids just yet, but when the time comes, I want to make sure I'm in a place where I can give them the same kind of love and support that my parents gave me.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how far I've come and the values that have shaped my journey. Talking about my life from the beginning reminded me of the strong foundation my parents gave me, even with their own limitations. The crossroads moment in college was a defining point for me—it showed me the importance of balancing duty with dreams, and how one decision can truly change the course of your life. I realized that while I made the choice to take the internship, I could have leaned on more support systems along the way, and that's something I've learned to be more open about now. Even though I don't have a partner or children yet, I know that family will always be central to who I am, and I want to carry forward the same love and support that my parents gave me. It was a good reminder that no matter how far you go, staying connected to your roots is essential.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Kevin Kozlowski: My sister, Anna, lives in Milwaukee now. She's a few years older than me, and she always had a different path in life. While I was focused on school and work, she went into the arts—she's a graphic designer and runs her own small studio. We didn't always see eye to eye growing up; she was more free-spirited, and I was the more practical one. But over the years, we've grown closer. She's always been there for me, even when I wasn't sure I needed her. We talk a lot, especially about life choices and what we want for the future. I admire her for taking risks and living the way she wants to. She's the one who encouraged me to think bigger when I was stuck in my routine. Even though we're different, I know she's family, and that means a lot to me. I visit her whenever I can, and we always have a great time catching up—whether it's over coffee or just hanging out at her place. She's one of the few people who really understands where I'm coming from, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Kevin Kozlowski: Yeah, there are definitely a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Mike, who I met in college. We were in the same business program, and we ended up rooming together for a couple of semesters. Mike was always the more outgoing one, and he pushed me to get involved in campus activities that I probably wouldn't have done on my own. After college, we both ended up working in marketing, though he took a different path—event planning, actually. He's always been the creative one, and I've always admired that about him. We haven't stayed as close as we used to, but we still keep in touch, especially around holidays or when we're both back in Chicago. I also have a few coworkers who have become good friends over the years—people I can count on for advice or just a laugh. I think the thing that matters most is that I've always tried to surround myself with people who challenge me and support me, even if we're not always in the same place in life.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Kevin Kozlowski: I currently live in a neighborhood on the North Side of Chicago, in a quiet apartment complex near Lake Michigan. It's a bit more upscale than where I grew up, but I like that it still has that community feel. There are a lot of young professionals and families in the area, and I've really come to appreciate the mix of cultures and the sense of safety that comes with it. I live in a one-bedroom apartment, which is just enough for me—no need for extra space when I'm single and focused on my work. The building has a nice common area with a small gym and a rooftop where I sometimes go to clear my head after a long day. I enjoy walking around the neighborhood, especially along the lakefront, where I can watch the sunset and reflect on my day. It's not the same as the South Side, but it's a place that feels like home now. I like knowing that I've built a life for myself, and I'm proud of how far I've come.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Kevin Kozlowski: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. The neighborhood has a good sense of community, and people look out for each other. I've never had any issues with crime or anything like that. It's one of the things I appreciate most about living here—knowing that I can walk outside at night without worrying too much. That said, I still keep my doors locked and try to be mindful, just like anywhere else. Safety is something I value, and I think it's a combination of the environment and the people in it. I don't feel like I'm in a bubble, but I also feel like I'm in a place where I can be comfortable and secure. It's a nice balance, and I think it's one of the reasons I've been able to focus on my work and personal goals without too much stress about my surroundings.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Kevin Kozlowski: Living here has definitely had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The upside is the sense of stability and the opportunities that come with being in a more established part of the city. I've been able to build a routine that works for me—early mornings at the gym, a good commute to work, and evenings spent either catching up on work or just relaxing with a book on the rooftop. I've also made some good connections with neighbors, and it's nice to know people here. That said, there are downs too. Sometimes I feel like I'm living a bit of a double life—between the quiet, professional environment I'm in now and the more vibrant, community-driven life I grew up with. I miss the sense of familiarity and the constant presence of family and friends from the South Side. It's not that I don't like it here, but I think I'm still figuring out how to balance the comfort of my current life with the roots I came from. I guess that's part of growing up—learning to hold on to what matters while also embracing the new.

Going through the recent interview questions about my family and current neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has changed over the years. It's interesting to think about how I've moved from the South Side to the North Side, and how my priorities have shifted along the way. I still value family deeply, and even though I don't have a partner or children yet, I know that when the time comes, I want to give them the same kind of love and support that my parents gave me. My neighborhood now feels safe and stable, which is something I really appreciate, but I also know that I carry a part of my roots with me no matter where I go. It's a balance I'm still learning to navigate, but I'm grateful for the people and experiences that have shaped me into who I am today.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Kevin Kozlowski: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but there's still some flexibility. I usually wake up around 6:30 a.m., make a quick breakfast, and head to the gym for an hour or so. That's something I've made a habit of since moving to the North Side—it helps me stay grounded and focused. From there, I commute into the city for work, which is about a 20-minute drive. My job in marketing keeps me pretty busy, so most days are similar: meetings, emails, and working on campaigns. I try to take lunch breaks outside when I can, sometimes grabbing a sandwich from one of the local cafes nearby. In the afternoons, I might meet up with a coworker for coffee or just work through the rest of the day. By the time I get home, I usually unwind with a movie or a book, especially on the rooftop where I can enjoy the view of the lake. Weekends are a bit more relaxed—I might catch up with friends, go for a walk, or just stay in and plan for the week ahead. It's a good rhythm, but I still find myself thinking about how different it is from the South Side, where life was more about family dinners and neighborhood gatherings. I guess I'm still learning how to make this place feel like home in a different way.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Kevin Kozlowski: I work full time as a marketing manager for a mid-sized company that specializes in digital campaigns for local businesses. My job is pretty demanding, but I enjoy the challenge of it. I usually start my workday around 9 a.m., though I'm often in the office by 8:30 to get a head start on the day. We have a lot of client meetings, strategy sessions, and creative brainstorming, so the schedule can vary a bit depending on the project. I work Monday through Friday, and while I do have some flexibility with my hours, I've found that sticking to a routine helps me stay productive. One of the things I like about my job is that it allows me to be creative while also giving me a sense of accomplishment when a campaign we worked on actually makes an impact. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm making the most of the opportunities I've been given, and that keeps me motivated.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Kevin Kozlowski: Outside of work, I also try to stay involved in a few community initiatives, especially ones that focus on youth education and career development. I volunteer a couple of hours a week at a local nonprofit that helps high school students prepare for college applications and internships. It's something I really enjoy because it reminds me of the support I received when I was younger, and I want to give back in whatever way I can. I also make it a point to keep up with my Polish heritage, even though I don't speak the language anymore. I still enjoy cooking some traditional dishes on weekends, and I've started learning a few phrases again just for fun. It's a small way to stay connected to my roots, and I think it helps me keep perspective on where I came from and where I'm going.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Kevin Kozlowski: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness into my mornings. I started doing a short meditation practice before heading to the gym, which has helped me stay more centered, especially with the demands of work and the balance I'm still trying to find between my current life and my roots. I also began taking evening walks along the lakefront a few times a week, not just for the exercise, but to clear my mind and reflect on the day. It's been a nice addition to my routine, and I've found that these small changes have made a big difference in how I feel overall. I think it's important to keep evolving, even in the little things, because that's how you grow and stay grounded.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Kevin Kozlowski: I don't have children yet, but I've thought a lot about what a typical weekday would look like for them if I did. I imagine waking up early, maybe around 7 a.m., with a calm morning routine—breakfast, some quiet time for reading or drawing, and then getting ready for school. I'd want them to have a balanced schedule, with time for academics, play, and family. After school, I'd love for them to participate in activities that interest them—maybe something like sports, music, or art. I think it's important for kids to explore their passions and build confidence through extracurriculars. I'd also make sure they have time to just be kids, to hang out with friends or family, and to enjoy the simple things. When the time comes, I want to be there for them, not just as a parent, but as a friend and a guide. I know I have a lot to learn, but I'm ready to grow with them and support them every step of the way.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me think deeply about how my life has evolved and the values that continue to shape me. Reflecting on my family, neighborhood, and daily routines reminded me of the balance I'm still learning to maintain between my roots and my current life. I'm grateful for the support my parents gave me growing up, and I want to carry that same sense of love and responsibility into whatever future I build. Living in my current neighborhood has brought a new kind of stability, but I still feel a strong connection to the South Side and the community that raised me. I also appreciate the small ways I can stay connected to my heritage, like volunteering and cooking traditional dishes. It's clear that growth isn't just about moving forward—it's about holding on to what matters while embracing the changes that come with it.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Kevin Kozlowski: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm in pretty good shape overall. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid—playing sports, running around with friends, that kind of thing. When I moved to the North Side, I made a conscious effort to keep that going, which is why I started going to the gym regularly. I try to eat well, mostly sticking to balanced meals—grilled chicken, veggies, whole grains. I know I'm not perfect, and there are definitely days when I slip up and grab something quick, but I've made an effort to be more mindful about what I eat. I also try to get enough sleep, though with a busy work schedule, it's not always easy. I've been dealing with some mild back pain lately, probably from sitting too long at my desk, so I've started doing some stretches and yoga in the evenings to help with that. I think the most important thing is that I'm aware of my body and I'm taking steps to take care of it. I don't want to take my health for granted, especially knowing how hard my parents worked to give me a good life. I want to make sure I'm around for the long haul, not just for myself, but for the people I care about.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Kevin Kozlowski: For me, what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine and the support of my environment. Living in a place where I can walk outside, get fresh air, and have access to a gym helps keep me on track. I also find that eating well is easier when I cook at home, which I do most nights. What makes it harder is the stress of work and the occasional late nights, which can lead to skipping meals or not getting enough sleep. I've learned that consistency is key, but there are definitely days when life gets in the way. I think the hardest part is staying motivated when things get busy, but I remind myself that taking care of my health isn't just about looking good—it's about being able to keep up with the people I care about and the life I've built. I'm still learning, but I'm committed to making it a priority.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Kevin Kozlowski: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some ongoing lower back pain, which I think is related to the long hours I spend sitting at my desk. It started as a mild discomfort, but over time, it's become more frequent, especially after long days at work. I've been seeing a chiropractor every few weeks, and they've been helping me manage it with adjustments and some exercises. I also started doing yoga a few months ago, which has been a big help in keeping the pain at bay. It's not something I ever expected to deal with, but I guess it's a reminder that even with the best intentions, our bodies can let us down if we're not careful. I've learned to listen to my body more and take breaks when I need to, which has made a real difference. I don't want this to become a bigger issue, so I'm committed to staying on top of it—whether that's through exercise, posture, or just being more mindful of how I spend my day.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Kevin Kozlowski: Honestly, the back pain hasn't really gotten in the way of my work or daily life—mostly because I've been proactive about managing it. I do have days where I feel it more, especially after a long meeting or a stressful project deadline, but I've learned to pace myself and take short breaks throughout the day. I've also made sure to adjust my workspace, like using an ergonomic chair and setting reminders to stand up and stretch. It's not perfect, but it's enough to keep me going. I know if I ignored it completely, it could become something bigger, so I try to stay on top of it. As for caring for children, I haven't had that experience yet, but I can imagine that health issues could definitely add another layer of complexity. That's why I want to be as healthy as I can be now—so that when the time comes, I'm in the best position possible to support a family. It's not just about me anymore; it's about being there for others too.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Kevin Kozlowski: Over the past year, I've been feeling pretty good overall, though there have been moments of reflection and growth. Life has been busy with work, but I've also made an effort to slow down and appreciate the little things. I've been more intentional about my time, whether it's spending weekends with my parents, catching up with my sister, or just enjoying the peace of the lakefront. I've also been thinking a lot about where I want to go next—both professionally and personally. I've started looking into some leadership training programs at work, which has been exciting but also a bit intimidating. It's a reminder that growth doesn't stop once you've achieved a certain level of success. I've also been trying to stay connected to my Polish heritage in more meaningful ways, like attending a few cultural events and reconnecting with some old family friends who moved back to Chicago. It's been a year of balance—between keeping my feet on the ground and reaching for something bigger. I know I'm not perfect, but I feel like I'm moving in the right direction, and that gives me a sense of peace.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily habits have shaped my sense of well-being and balance in life. It's interesting to think about how something as simple as a morning meditation or an evening walk can make such a difference in how I feel overall. I've always known the importance of taking care of my body, especially after seeing how hard my parents worked to give me a good life, but it's only recently that I've started to truly prioritize it in a consistent way. I've also come to realize that health isn't just about physical fitness—it's about mental and emotional balance too. The back pain I've been dealing with is a reminder that even small changes, like posture and stretching, can have a big impact. I'm grateful for the support of my environment and the routines I've built, but I know there's still more to learn. It's comforting to know that I'm not perfect, but I'm making an effort to grow and stay grounded in the things that matter most.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Kevin Kozlowski: Honestly, I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do, but I think everyone has their moments. There have been times when the pressure of work or the weight of responsibility felt overwhelming, especially when I was younger and trying to figure out my path. I remember feeling a bit lost after college, not sure if I was making the right choices or if I was moving in the direction I wanted. But I've always tried to push through, even if it wasn't easy. I think what helps me the most is staying connected to the people I care about—my family, my sister, my friends. They're my grounding force. I also find that having a routine, whether it's going to the gym, meditating, or just taking a walk, helps me stay balanced. I know I'm not immune to stress or doubt, but I've learned to recognize when I need to slow down and take a step back. I think the key is not ignoring those feelings, but also not letting them define me. I'm still learning, but I feel like I'm in a better place now than I was a few years ago.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Kevin Kozlowski: For my family, the past year has been a mix of stability and quiet growth. My parents are both doing well, though they've had their own moments of reflection as they've settled into retirement. My mom still volunteers at the hospital, which gives her a sense of purpose, and my dad has taken up some small home improvement projects, which keeps him busy and engaged. They've always been proud of me, but I think they've started to see me not just as their son, but as someone who's carved out his own path. I've made it a point to visit them more often, and we've had some really meaningful conversations about life, family, and what the future holds. My sister, Anna, has been going through her own changes too—she recently moved into a new studio space and is working on a big project that's been taking up a lot of her time. Even though we're different in so many ways, I know she's always had my back, and that means a lot to me. I think the past year has been about finding balance for all of us, and I'm grateful for the love and support that keeps us connected no matter where life takes us.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Kevin Kozlowski: When it comes to religion or spirituality, I think I've always been somewhere in the middle. I was raised Catholic, and I remember going to church with my family when I was younger—it was a part of our routine, and I appreciated the sense of community and structure it provided. But as I got older, especially after college, I started to question a lot of things. I didn't feel like I needed to follow the same path my parents did, and I found myself more interested in personal reflection than in organized religion. Now, I wouldn't say I'm spiritual in the traditional sense, but I do believe in the importance of mindfulness, gratitude, and staying connected to the people and values that matter most. I think of it more as a way of living than a belief system. I still respect the role religion played in shaping my early life, and I appreciate the traditions I grew up with, but I've come to see spirituality as something more personal and flexible. It's not something I talk about a lot, but it's something I carry with me in how I approach life and the choices I make.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Kevin Kozlowski: I don't use social media all that much, honestly. I've always been more of a private person, and I find that platforms like Facebook or Instagram can be a bit overwhelming with all the noise and comparisons. That said, I do use LinkedIn occasionally for professional networking, especially when I'm looking into new opportunities or connecting with people in my industry. I also have a few friends who post regularly, and I'll check in on their updates now and then, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or engaging with content. I think it's important to stay connected, but I also value my privacy and the quiet moments that don't involve screens. I prefer face-to-face interactions or even a simple phone call when I want to catch up with someone. It's not that I'm anti-social media—it's just not a big part of my life the way it is for some people. I think I'm more of a 'less is more' kind of guy when it comes to that.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Kevin Kozlowski: Honestly, I don't rely on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I've always found that the people I care about—my family, my sister, my friends—are more than enough. When I'm going through something, I prefer talking to someone face-to-face or over the phone rather than posting about it online. I think there's a difference between sharing your struggles and seeking real help. I've been fortunate to have a strong support system, and I don't want to minimize that by turning to something that feels more like a distraction than a solution. That said, I can see how it might work for others, especially if they're more comfortable expressing themselves that way. For me, it's just not my go-to. I trust the people in my life, and I think that's where real support comes from.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how my health and mental well-being have become more important to me as I've grown older. It's interesting to think about how something as simple as back pain can remind me to take better care of my body and adjust my habits for the long term. I've also come to realize that while I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do, I'm not immune to stress or doubt. What helps me the most is staying connected to the people I care about—my family, my sister, and my friends. They're my grounding force, and I'm grateful for their support. I've learned that it's okay to slow down and take a step back when life feels overwhelming, and I'm trying to be more intentional about how I approach both my health and my mental state. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm making progress, and that gives me a sense of peace.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Kevin Kozlowski: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have actually decreased a bit, which is something I didn't expect. I think it's because I've been more intentional about how I manage my time and what I prioritize. I've started setting clearer boundaries between work and personal life, which has helped me feel more in control. I also find that my emotional coping strategies have evolved—I used to rely more on pushing through stress, but now I'm more open to slowing down and taking a step back when needed. I've been practicing mindfulness more consistently, and that's made a real difference in how I handle difficult situations. I also talk to my sister or my parents more often when I feel overwhelmed, which gives me a sense of grounding. I think the key has been learning to accept that it's okay not to have everything figured out all the time. I'm still figuring things out, but I feel more at peace with the process now.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Kevin Kozlowski: In terms of making ends meet, I've always been pretty careful with my money, especially growing up in a working-class family. My biggest expenses last month were rent, which is a chunk of my paycheck, and groceries—especially since I've been cooking more at home these days. I also have a car payment, insurance, and some savings contributions, which I try to keep up with even if it's not a lot. I don't spend much on entertainment or luxury items, but I do set aside a small amount for things like books or a weekend trip if I can afford it. I've learned to live within my means, and while I'm not rolling in wealth, I feel like I'm in a good place financially. It's not about having more—it's about being responsible and making sure I'm prepared for the future, whether that's for a family someday or just having a little cushion for unexpected things. I know it's not perfect, but I'm proud of how I've managed to build a stable life for myself.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Kevin Kozlowski: My household spending last month was pretty much in line with what I usually spend. I'd say it came out to around $2,500, give or take a few hundred. The bulk of that goes to rent, which is about $1,200 a month, and groceries, which I try to keep around $400. I also have a car payment of about $300, plus insurance and other bills that add up to another $400 or so. I set aside a little bit each month for savings—maybe $200 or so—and I also spend a small amount on things like books, coffee, or a weekend outing if I can afford it. It's not a lot, but it's enough to live comfortably and stay on top of my responsibilities. I've always been careful with money, especially growing up in a working-class family, so I try to stick to a budget and not overspend. It's not about luxury for me—it's about stability and being prepared for whatever comes next.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Kevin Kozlowski: We rent our home, actually. I've always preferred renting over owning, especially given the way my life has evolved over the years. Renting gives me more flexibility, which is something I value, especially since I'm still figuring out where I want to be in the next few years. My apartment is in a great location, close to work and the lakefront, which makes it easier to maintain a good work-life balance. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon—there's just something about the freedom of renting that I really like. Plus, with the way the housing market is, I think it's smarter to stay flexible for now. I'm not saying I'll never own a home, but for now, renting feels like the right choice for me.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Kevin Kozlowski: Over the past year, my bills have had some fluctuations, mostly tied to the seasons and a few unexpected expenses. For example, during the winter months, my heating bill went up a bit, which is something I didn't budget for as much as I should have. I also had to replace my car's brakes last spring, which was an unplanned expense that added a few hundred dollars to my monthly costs. On the other hand, some things have stayed pretty consistent—like my rent and insurance. I also noticed that my grocery bills tend to go up around the holidays, especially when I'm cooking more meals at home for family gatherings. I've been trying to track my spending more closely now, using a simple budgeting app to keep things in check. It's not perfect, but it's helped me stay aware of where my money is going and make adjustments when needed. I think the key is being flexible and not getting too stressed about small changes—it's all about finding a balance that works for me.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me think about how much my family and my approach to emotional support have shaped my life. It's comforting to know that my parents are doing well and finding purpose in their retirement, and that my sister continues to be a strong presence in my life. I've always known that my family is my foundation, and it's reassuring to see that they're still growing and finding meaning in their own ways. At the same time, I've come to realize that while I don't rely on social media for support, I do value the real, personal connections I have with the people I care about. I've learned that true support comes from face-to-face conversations, not from screens or posts. It's a reminder that I'm lucky to have a strong support system, and I'm grateful for the people who have always been there for me, even when I didn't ask for it.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Kevin Kozlowski: I do save, though it's not always a huge amount. I've always believed in setting aside even a little each month, just to build some kind of cushion. Right now, I contribute about $200 a month to a savings account, and I also have a small emergency fund that I try to keep replenished. I know it's not a lot compared to what some people have, but for me, it's about being responsible and prepared. I've seen how hard my parents worked to provide for me, and I want to make sure I'm not caught off guard if something unexpected comes up. I also try to save for bigger goals, like maybe buying a house someday or taking a trip. It's not always easy, especially with the way my income is, but I think it's important to have that sense of security. I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about having a lot—it's about being thoughtful and consistent, even in small ways.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Kevin Kozlowski: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for bigger goals, though I'm still figuring out exactly what those bigger goals look like. The emergency fund is definitely my priority right now—especially with the back pain I've been dealing with, I want to make sure I have some financial cushion in case I need to take time off or make unexpected medical decisions. I also started setting aside a little extra each month for something bigger, like maybe a trip or even a down payment on a house someday. It's not something I've thought about too much yet, but I know I'll get there. For now, it's about being responsible and making sure I'm not caught off guard. I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about having a lot—it's about being thoughtful and consistent, even in small ways.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Kevin Kozlowski: My occupation is as a marketing manager for a mid-sized company that specializes in digital campaigns for local businesses. In this role, I oversee the development and execution of marketing strategies, manage a small team of creatives and analysts, and work closely with clients to understand their goals and tailor campaigns that resonate with their target audiences. The most important activities include brainstorming creative concepts, analyzing data to measure campaign performance, and presenting insights to stakeholders. I also spend a lot of time collaborating with other departments, like sales and customer service, to ensure our messaging is consistent and effective. What I enjoy most about the job is the challenge of thinking outside the box and seeing the impact of our work—whether it's helping a small business increase its visibility or contributing to a campaign that makes a real difference in the community. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm making the most of the opportunities I've been given, and that keeps me motivated.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Kevin Kozlowski: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, depending on the project deadlines and how much is going on with the team. There are weeks where it feels like I'm working nonstop, especially when we're launching a new campaign or preparing for a big client presentation. But I've learned to manage my time better over the years, and I try to stick to a routine as much as possible. I know that work is important, but I also know that balance is key. That's why I make sure to take those evenings at the lakefront or go to the gym in the mornings—it helps me stay grounded and reminds me that I'm not just working for the sake of work. I've seen what it's like for my parents, who always put in long hours but never had the chance to really take a break. I want to make sure I don't end up in the same place, so I try to be intentional about how I spend my time, both at work and at home.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Kevin Kozlowski: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on building a solid career in marketing, and while there were a few times when I took on freelance projects or side gigs—like helping a local business with their social media in the early days of my career—it was never something I did full-time. I think part of that comes from growing up in a family where both my parents worked hard but didn't have the luxury of multiple income streams. I always wanted to make sure that whatever I did was something I could commit to fully, especially since I knew how much it meant to my parents to have stability. I've never been one for spreading myself too thin, and I think that's why I've been able to focus on growing in my current role without getting distracted by too many other things. It's not that I don't like the idea of having more than one job—it's just that I've always believed in doing one thing well and making the most of it.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how my approach to stress, emotional support, and financial stability has evolved over the past year. It's interesting to think about how my stress levels have actually decreased, not because life has gotten easier, but because I've learned to manage it better. Setting clearer boundaries between work and personal life has helped me feel more in control, and I've grown more comfortable with slowing down and taking a step back when needed. I've also come to appreciate the importance of real, personal connections—talking to my sister or my parents when I feel overwhelmed gives me a sense of grounding that no screen or post ever could. Financially, I've always been careful with my money, especially growing up in a working-class family, and I feel proud of how I've managed to build a stable life for myself. It's not about having more—it's about being responsible and making sure I'm prepared for whatever comes next. I know I'm not perfect, but I'm making progress, and that gives me a sense of peace.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Kevin Kozlowski: In terms of my household income, I'd say we made around $5,000 last month, which is pretty much in line with what I usually earn. My salary as a marketing manager covers most of it, and I've been fortunate to have a stable position that allows me to meet my expenses without too much stress. I know it's not a huge amount, but it's enough to live comfortably, save a little, and still enjoy the things that matter most—like spending time with family or taking a walk by the lake. I've always been careful with money, especially growing up in a working-class family, so I try to stick to a budget and not overspend. It's not about luxury for me—it's about stability and being prepared for whatever comes next.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Kevin Kozlowski: I've been at my current job for about five years now, and it's been a good fit for me. The company has a strong culture that values teamwork and innovation, which I really appreciate. As for the benefits, we have a solid health insurance plan that covers most of my medical needs, including the chiropractic care I've been using for my back pain. We also get a generous amount of paid time off—about three weeks of vacation, plus sick days and holidays. I think the most important thing for me is that the company offers a flexible work schedule, which helps me maintain that balance between work and personal life. I've seen a lot of people in my industry burn out because they don't take enough time to rest, and I want to make sure I don't end up in that place. The benefits aren't just about money or perks—they're about supporting a sustainable lifestyle, and I feel lucky to have that in my job.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Kevin Kozlowski: My relationships at work are pretty good overall—I feel like I have a solid support system here. My manager is someone I respect a lot; she's been a mentor to me since I started and has always encouraged me to take on challenges that push me out of my comfort zone. She's fair, transparent, and doesn't hesitate to give feedback when needed. I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to grow so much in this role. As for my coworkers, we have a good dynamic. We collaborate a lot, especially when we're working on tight deadlines, and I've built some really strong friendships with a few of them. We're all in the same boat, trying to make our campaigns work and meet client expectations, so there's a sense of camaraderie. That said, I'm not one to get too close professionally—I think there's a balance between being a team player and maintaining personal boundaries. I value the relationships I have at work, but I also know that my family and personal life are what truly ground me. I'm grateful for the support I get here, but I'm always mindful of not letting work consume everything.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Kevin Kozlowski: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's still some flexibility depending on the project. Most days, I start around 9 a.m. and leave around 6 p.m., though I often stay a little later when we're wrapping up a big campaign or preparing for a client meeting. The company allows for some remote work, which I've taken advantage of a few times, especially when I need to focus or when I'm feeling under the weather. That said, I do prefer being in the office most of the time because I find that in-person collaboration sparks more creativity and keeps the team aligned. I also appreciate that I can adjust my hours a bit if needed, which helps me maintain that balance between work and personal life. It's not perfect, but I think the flexibility I have now is a big part of why I've been able to stay motivated and grounded in my role.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Kevin Kozlowski: Overall, I feel pretty good about my financial situation. It's not extravagant, but it's stable, and I know I've worked hard to get to this point. Growing up in a working-class family, I always had a respect for money and the importance of using it wisely. I've never been one to chase luxury or live beyond my means, and I think that's helped me build a sense of security. I'm able to cover my expenses, save a little each month, and still have the freedom to enjoy the things I love—like spending time with my family or taking a walk by the lake. I know there's always room for growth, and I'm not naive about the fact that things could change, but for now, I feel like I'm in a good place. It's not about having more—it's about being responsible and knowing that I've built a life that's sustainable, both for me and for whatever the future might bring.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how my financial habits and work-life balance have shaped my sense of stability and peace. It's interesting to think about how my bills fluctuate over the course of a year—some months are more predictable, while others bring unexpected expenses like car repairs or higher heating costs. I've learned to be more mindful of tracking my spending, and it's helped me stay in control of my finances even when things don't go as planned. At the same time, I've come to appreciate the importance of setting boundaries at work, especially after seeing how my parents worked long hours without much time for themselves. I want to make sure I don't end up in the same place, so I try to be intentional about how I spend my time, both at work and at home. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm making progress, and that gives me a sense of peace.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Kevin Kozlowski: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad was a mechanic, and he worked at a local garage for over 20 years—probably the longest he's ever held a job. He always said he liked the hands-on work, even though it was physically demanding. My mom worked as a nurse's aide at a hospital, and she put in long hours, often working double shifts when the hospital was short-staffed. They both worked hard to provide for our family, and I think that's why I've always had a strong work ethic. I remember seeing them sacrifice a lot, like skipping meals or not taking time off when they were sick, just to make sure I had everything I needed. It's one of the reasons I value stability and responsibility so much—it's not just about me anymore; it's about making sure I'm not repeating the same struggles they faced, but also about honoring the sacrifices they made for me.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Kevin Kozlowski: My dad was a mechanic, and his most important duties involved diagnosing and repairing cars, trucks, and other vehicles that came into the garage. He had a real knack for figuring out what was wrong with a machine just by listening to it or looking at it—like he could tell if something was off without even touching the engine. He worked long hours, often coming in early and staying late, especially when the shop was busy or when a customer needed something fixed right away. He always took pride in his work, and I remember him telling me that he didn't just fix cars; he fixed people's lives, because without a working vehicle, a lot of folks couldn't get to work or take care of their families. My mom, on the other hand, worked as a nurse's aide, which meant she was on her feet all day, helping patients with their daily needs—feeding them, helping them move, and just being there for them when they needed someone to talk to. She had a quiet strength about her, and I think that's why she was so respected at the hospital. Both of them had jobs that weren't glamorous, but they were essential, and they taught me the value of hard work, responsibility, and putting others first. I think that's why I've always felt a deep sense of gratitude for them, and why I try to live in a way that honors the sacrifices they made for me.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Kevin Kozlowski: My dad worked at a local garage called Kozlowski Auto Repair—it was a family-owned business, actually, though he was the only one working there after my grandfather retired. It was a small shop, but it had a good reputation in the neighborhood. They did everything from oil changes to full engine overhauls, and my dad was known for his attention to detail and his ability to fix almost anything. My mom worked at St. Mary's Hospital as a nurse's aide. It was a busy place, especially during the day shifts, and she was always on her feet, helping patients with their daily routines, making sure they were comfortable, and sometimes just listening to them when they needed someone to talk to. Both of them made a good living for our family, though it wasn't extravagant. They always said they were lucky to have steady jobs, and I think that's why I've always valued stability and responsibility so much. I remember seeing them work long hours, sometimes coming home exhausted, but they never complained. They just did what they had to do to make sure I had everything I needed. That's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Kevin Kozlowski: A few years from now, I hope I'm still in a place where I can continue growing both personally and professionally, but also where I'm not losing touch with the things that matter most. I see myself still working in marketing, maybe in a leadership role, but not just for the sake of climbing the ladder—I want to make sure I'm making an impact, helping others, and mentoring people the way I was mentored. I also hope I'm more settled in my personal life, whether that means having a partner or not, but I definitely want to be in a position where I can support a family if that's what I choose. I hope I'm still living in Chicago, maybe a bit further out, with a bigger space where I can have a garden or at least a few plants—something that feels like home. I want to keep staying connected to my roots, to my family, and to the community that helped shape me. I hope I'm still volunteering, still learning, and still finding ways to give back. Most of all, I hope I'm happy—not because everything is perfect, but because I'm at peace with where I am and where I'm going.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Kevin Kozlowski: What I value the most in my life is the balance between who I am and who I want to become. I value family above all else—my parents, my sister, and the extended family that's always been there for me. They've shaped me in ways I can't even fully articulate, and I want to make sure I carry that love and support forward, whether it's through my own family someday or just being there for the people I care about. I also value growth, both personal and professional. I don't want to stay stagnant; I want to keep learning, keep challenging myself, and keep pushing forward in a way that's meaningful. I value stability, not because I'm afraid of change, but because it gives me the freedom to take risks and explore new things without fear. And I value connection—whether it's through my work, my community, or the simple moments with the people I love. Life is about more than just getting by; it's about making sure you're living with purpose, and I want to make sure I'm always doing that.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my financial habits, work-life balance, and relationships at work have shaped my sense of stability and peace. It's interesting to think about how my bills fluctuate over the course of a year—some months are more predictable, while others bring unexpected expenses like car repairs or higher heating costs. I've learned to be more mindful of tracking my spending, and it's helped me stay in control of my finances even when things don't go as planned. At the same time, I've come to appreciate the importance of setting boundaries at work, especially after seeing how my parents worked long hours without much time for themselves. I want to make sure I don't end up in the same place, so I try to be intentional about how I spend my time, both at work and at home. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm making progress, and that gives me a sense of peace.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, not just about where I've been, but also about where I'm headed. It's amazing how much my roots in Chicago's South Side have shaped who I am today—my work ethic, my values, and my deep connection to family. The crossroads moment in college, where I chose to take the internship over a part-time job to support my parents, was a defining point in my life. It taught me the importance of balancing responsibility with ambition, and that decision ultimately led me to the career I have now. I've also come to appreciate the support systems I had, even if I didn't realize it at the time. My parents' sacrifices, my sister's encouragement, and the friends I've made along the way have all played a role in shaping my path. Living in the North Side now has brought a new kind of stability, but I still carry a part of my roots with me. I've learned that growth isn't just about moving forward—it's about holding on to what matters while embracing the changes that come with it. I'm grateful for the people and experiences that have shaped me into who I am today, and I look forward to continuing that journey with purpose and peace.
